Connects high-profile figures (like the Cabell brothers and Allen Dulles) to the JFK assassination, recognizing conflicts of interest in the investigation; demonstrates informed insight and an ability to make strategic decisions like issuing subpoenas.

Re-elected to a third term as District Attorney of Orleans Parish, defending himself successfully in Federal Court against framed charges.
Divorced from Elizabeth but continues to live in the same house nearby, maintaining proximity to his family.
Narrowly defeated for a fourth term as District Attorney after legal troubles.
Re-elected to a third term as District Attorney of Orleans Parish in November 1969.

Arrested by Federal Agents on charges of allowing payoffs on pinball gambling by organized crime; defended himself in Federal Court and was quickly found not guilty, suggesting skill in legal defense.
Narrowly defeated for a fourth term as District Attorney less than six weeks after being acquitted.
Elected Judge of the Louisiana State Court of Appeal in New Orleans in 1978 and re-elected in 1988.
Brought the only public prosecution in the Kennedy killing to date.
Was divorced in 1978; no direct connection to competence inferred.
